nodes.text: Hypothetical bias in stated choice experiments affects the external validity of choice experiments (CEs) by causing deviations between hypothetical survey-derived measures and those from more realistic settings
Choice experiments are widely used across environmental, consumer, health and transport economics to infer preferences and value attributes for policy and market decisions

Systematic literature search in Web of Science plus supplementary searches produced a core dataset of 57 peer-reviewed empirical studies testing HB in CEs (searched 2018, updated 2020) and an additional set of psychology/neuroscience studies
Empirical evidence on hypothetical bias in CEs is mixed overall and is context-, measurement- and discipline-dependent

In health economics studies HB is often absent or negligible, with within-subject comparisons showing good predictive sensitivity for positive choices and many studies reporting no significant bias after scale adjustment
Transport and many consumer studies often find significant HB; transport studies frequently report downward bias in monetary valuation of travel time savings (SP < RP)

Many studies observe systematic scale differences between hypothetical (SP) and more realistic (RP or incentivised) data; scale correction can reconcile marginal rates of substitution even when total WTP or opt-in rates differ
Operationalisation and measurement of HB in CEs vary widely (e.g., total WTP, marginal WTP, market shares, opt-in rates, simulated probabilities), which impedes consistent comparison across studies

Psychology and neuroimaging studies identify cognitive mechanisms (e.g., hot-cold empathy gaps, differential brain activation strength for real vs hypothetical choices) that can produce or explain observed HB patterns, including reversed bias for aversive 'bads'

Identified sources of HB include lack of incentive/payment consequentiality, lack of policy consequentiality, social desirability and warm-glow motivations, strategic misrepresentation, cognitive dissonance and choice-induced preference change, information and attribute salience, and lack of experience or dynamic learning

Moderating factors that influence magnitude/direction of HB include respondent characteristics (gender, personality, familiarity), good type (public vs private, moral/social component, desirable vs aversive), stake size and bid range, payment vehicle, design features (opt-out, within vs between subjects), and presentation/ecological validity

Proposed unified definition: hypothetical bias is the deviation in a predefined aggregate or disaggregate measure due to choice data being collected in a hypothetical setting instead of a more realistic (but not necessarily naturalistic) setting; five classes of benchmark realism (I to V) are defined

Mitigation and testing recommendations: use context-specific benchmarks of greater realism (classes II-V), incentive alignment where feasible, enhance contextual tangibility (e.g., VR, simulators, real experience), apply scale corrections, and target mitigation to identified sources

Synthesis limitations: scarcity of true naturalistic RP benchmarks, heterogeneity in HB definitions and measures across disciplines, and difficulty of testing novel/nonmarket alternatives constrain comprehensive meta-analysis
Many studies report HB in total willingness-to-pay estimates and opt-in rates but not in hypothetical marginal rates of substitution after accounting for scale differences
